metadata.titel_preek: First Sunday in Lent: Psalm 19 & Psalm 51

primair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: God intervenes in the human condition of universal sin and self-deception to justify the ungodly through the substitutionary death of Christ.

subject.identificatie: God (specifically in the person of Jesus Christ)
tekstueel_bewijs: God has shown us a great thing.
Jesus, the Son of God, has voluntarily taken our place.
He has wrought the salvation of his enemies.

object.identificatie: Salvation, justification, and the 'cleansing of secret faults'
tekstueel_bewijs: wrought the salvation of his enemies

zender.identificatie: The Holy God / The Reality of God
tekstueel_bewijs: the power of God, the holiness of God, who has the absolute right to make demands

helper.identificatie: Jesus Christ (as the one who takes the sentence)
tekstueel_bewijs: There is Another who has taken the sentence upon himself

tegenstander.identificatie: Sin as a Cosmic Power and Human Self-Defense/Pretense
tekstueel_bewijs: storm of the wrath of God against sin
the line separating good and evil passes... right through every human heart
tegenstander.toelichting_ernst: Sin is treated not as a mistake but as a condition requiring a 'Subject-switch' to Christ because humans are 'helpless'.

secundair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The human response of repentance and honest self-inventory (Lenten discipline).
secundair_narratief_programma.subject: The Hearer/Believer
secundair_narratief_programma.toelichting_verhouding: The preacher explicitly states that the knowledge of grace precedes the confession of sin. The secondary program is a response to the primary.

voorbeelden_god_subject: God has shown us a great thing.
God made Jesus to be sin.
He has wrought the salvation of his enemies.
voorbeelden_mens_subject: We throw ourselves on his mercy.
We do not need to surround ourselves with defenses.

voorbeelden: action has to be taken against evil deeds
Our temptation will be... to try to squirm off the hook
The Bible teaches us to see ourselves as God sees us.
God is truly able to do away with sin.
While we were still helpless, Christ died.

modale_analyse.modale_interpretatie: The sermon emphasizes human 'non-pouvoir' (helplessness) and God's absolute 'pouvoir' (ability to save/create a clean heart).

semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.beweging_in_preek: Moves from the false security of ~S2 (denying sin) to the reality of S2 (God's case against us), then shows Christ taking S2 to bring the hearer to S1.
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.theologische_resolutie: Substitutionary atonement: Christ becomes sin (S2) so we become righteousness (S1).
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.ernst_van_s2: High; sin is described as a 'storm of wrath' and a 'sentence'.

diagnostische_evaluatie.classificatie_toelichting: The sermon consistently places God as the active Subject of salvation and defines the human condition as one of total helplessness requiring external rescue.

indicatoren_moralisme.tekstueel_bewijs: Our two greatest presidents... both called the nation to repentance.

indicatoren_genade.tekstueel_bewijs: There is Another who has taken the sentence upon himself.
The knowledge of grace has preceded the confession of sin.

exemplarisme_check.beschrijving: Biblical figures (David) are used as examples of 'self-knowledge' and 'petition' rather than moral models to imitate.
bijbelse_figuren_als_model: The Psalmist (as a model of honesty, not virtue)
exemplarisme_check.alternatieve_lezing: The sermon already treats David theocentrically: God is the one who creates the clean heart.

identificatie_patroon.effect_op_hoorder: Relief from the 'exhausting charade' of self-justification.
identificatie_patroon.theologische_implicatie: Monergistic salvation; justification by faith alone.

narratieve_coherentie.coherentie_beschrijving: The transition from the 'line through the heart' (Hamartology) to 'Christ died for the ungodly' (Soteriology) is seamless.

soteriologie.tekstueel_bewijs: Jesus, the Son of God, has voluntarily taken our place.

pneumatologie.competentie_schenking: The Spirit is the one who 'creates' and 'renews' what the human cannot.

hamartologie.ernst_diagnose: Total; sin is 'from birth' and 'secret', requiring a 'new creation'.

aanbevelingen.actantiele_audit_samenvatting: The sermon is a textbook example of a theocentric narrative where God is the Subject of all transformative verbs.

modale_balans.voorgestelde_balans: Maintain as is; this is appropriate for a Lent/Ash Wednesday context.

aanbevelingen.slotopmerking: This sermon masterfully avoids the trap of 'Lenten moralism' by making the confession of sin a response to grace rather than a condition for it.

comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_retorische_analyse: A rhetorical analysis might focus on the use of Tolkien/Solzhenitsyn as 'hooks'; Greimasian analysis shows they serve to establish the 'Opponent' as universal and internal.
comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_exegese: Exegesis explains the Hebrew of Psalm 51; this analysis reveals that the sermon's 'engine' is the substitutionary logic of 2 Cor 5:21.
comparatieve_analyse.unieke_inzichten_greimas: Reveals that the 'insight' of repentance is actually a modal competence (Savoir-faire) granted by the Sender, not a work of the Subject.

appendices.notities: The sermon uses Fleming Rutledge's own principles of 'God as Subject' effectively.
